content:
NetTcpSecurity Class

In this Article

Specifies the types of transport-level and message-level security used by an endpoint configured with a NetTcpBinding.

Syntax

Declaration

public sealed class NetTcpSecurity

Inheritance Hierarchy

  • System.Object
  • NetTcpSecurity

Inherited Members

Equals(Object)
,
Equals(Object,Object)
,
GetHashCode()
,
GetType()
,
MemberwiseClone()
,
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
,
ToString()

Remarks

Each of the standard bindings provides parameters for controlling the transfer security requirements. These parameters typically include the security mode that specified whether message-level or transport-level security is used and the choice of client credential type. Based on the choice of options these parameters present, a channel stack is constructed with appropriate security.

The system-provided bindings supplied by Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) are a set designed to meet some of the most common scenario requirements. Each of these bindings allows the specification of security requirements for some specific targeted scenarios.

NetTcpSecurity provides the security specifications for NetTcpBinding. This is a secure, reliable, optimized binding suitable for cross-machine communication. By default it generates a run-time communication stack that supports TCP for message delivery and Windows Security for message security and authentication, WS-ReliableMessaging for reliability, and binary message encoding.

This class is instantiated by the NetTcpBinding, and can be accessed by a read-only property called Security. Because this property is read-only you cannot make changes to the returned object. If you want to control the creation of the NetTcpSecurity object, you can derive a class from NetTcpBinding.

Constructors summary

NetTcpSecurity()

Initializes a new instance of the NetTcpSecurity class.

Properties summary

Message

Gets the type of message-level security requirements for a service configured with a NetTcpBinding.
Mode

Gets or sets whether message-level security and transport-level security are used by an endpoint configured with a NetTcpBinding.
Transport

Gets the type of message-level security requirements for an endpoint configured with a NetTcpBinding.

Constructors

  • NetTcpSecurity()

    Initializes a new instance of the NetTcpSecurity class.

    public NetTcpSecurity ();

Properties

  • Message

    Gets the type of message-level security requirements for a service configured with a NetTcpBinding.

    public System.ServiceModel.MessageSecurityOverTcp Message { get; set; }

    Property Value

    • MessageSecurityOverTcp

      The MessageSecurityOverTcp that indicates the type of message-level security requirements for an endpoint.

    Remarks

    Message uses message-level security for the integrity and confidentiality of the SOAP message and for mutual authentication of the communication peers. If this security mode is selected on a binding, the channel stack is configured with message security binding elements and the SOAP messages are secured in compliance with WS-Security* standards.

    Example

                    NetTcpSecurity security = binding.Security;
                MessageSecurityOverTcp msTcp = security.Message;

                Console.WriteLine("Dumping NetTcpSecurity object:");
                Console.WriteLine("    MessageSecurityOverTcp:");
                Console.WriteLine("        Algorithm Suite: {0}", msTcp.AlgorithmSuite);
                Console.WriteLine("        Client Credential Type: {0}", msTcp.ClientCredentialType);
  • Mode

    Gets or sets whether message-level security and transport-level security are used by an endpoint configured with a NetTcpBinding.

    public System.ServiceModel.SecurityMode Mode { get; set; }

    Property Value

    • SecurityMode

      A value of the SecurityMode that indicates whether message-level security or transport-level security is used by an endpoint. The default value is SecurityMode.

    Exceptions

    • ArgumentOutOfRangeException

      The value is not defined.

    Remarks

    The security mode determines the type of security required by an endpoint. Windows Communication Foundation (WCF) security offers a variety of mechanisms with which to secure the transfer of messages that are configured with the system-provided bindings. Each of the bindings supports a subset of these security modes. The mode determines the mechanisms by which message transfer security functions (integrity, confidentiality and authentication) are required.

    Example

                    NetTcpSecurity security = binding.Security;
                Console.WriteLine("    Security Mode: {0}", security.Mode);
  • Transport

    Gets the type of message-level security requirements for an endpoint configured with a NetTcpBinding.

    public System.ServiceModel.TcpTransportSecurity Transport { get; set; }

    Property Value

    • TcpTransportSecurity

      The TcpTransportSecurity that indicates the type of transport-level security requirements for an endpoint.

    Remarks

    Use Transport security for integrity and confidentiality of the SOAP message and for mutual authentication. If this security mode is selected on a binding, the channel stack is configured using a secure transport and the SOAP messages are secured using transport security such as HTTPS or SSL over TCP.

    Example

                    TcpTransportSecurity tsTcp = security.Transport;
                Console.WriteLine("    TcpTransportSecurity:");
                Console.WriteLine("        Client Credential Type: {0}", tsTcp.ClientCredentialType);
                Console.WriteLine("        ProtectionLevel: {0}", tsTcp.ProtectionLevel);
